awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: First Science with the Michigan Young STar Imager at CHARA (MYSTIC)
awd_abstract_narration:
The number of exoplanets--planets around stars other than the Sun--has grown into the thousands in the past decade. The vast majority of the known exoplanets have been found closer to their star than the Earth is to our Sun. At the distances of stars, this is too small a spacing to be easily resolved. The investigators plan to use a new technique (infrared interferometry) and a new instrument (MYSTIC), to study how Earth-like planets form and develop. Preliminary studies of planets suggest a gap in planet size distribution between 1.5 and 2 times the radius of the Earth, and the investigators will seek to confirm or disprove that result. Graduate students and undergraduate students will be involved in the research. The investigators will also team with the Ann Arbor Hands-On Museum to 1) create mobile versions of museum displays that will travel the state of Michigan and 2) create a hands-on exhibit and booth to travel to NASCAR events in Michigan in order to provide science outreach to an audience that might not currently be seeking STEM experiences.

The region inside 1 au around young stars is physically small on an astronomical scale. However, the physics in this region has an out-sized impact: this is where mass accretion onto the star is regulated, the initial conditions for terrestrial planet formation are set, and the migration of giant planets moving through the young gas-rich disk are controlled, Exoplanet demographics of the inner au now reveal a gap in the planet size distribution and also suggest the budget of solids available may not be enough to explain the known Kepler planets, at least using current disk models. To directly address the intimate connections between planet-formation theory and exoplanet demographics, spatially-resolved imaging of the inner au of young stars is needed. This can only be reached through infrared interferometry. Using the Georgia State University CHARA Array (the longest-baseline optical/infrared interferometer in the world) the investigators will image young stars with milliarcsecond angular resolution at wavelengths from 1.1-2.5 microns for the first time.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This collaborative research, involving Prof. Monnier's team at University
of Michigan and Prof. Baron's team at Georgia State University, aimed at
imaging young stars with unprecedented angular resolution at near-infrared
wavelengths (astronomical J,H,K bands) for the first time. To this end it used the NSF-funded instruments MIRCX and MYSTIC installed at the Center for High Angular Resolution Astronomy (CHARA), which combine the light from all six CHARA telescopes. This was the first MYSTIC science campaign project, a multi-wavelength, multi-epoch imaging survey of the inner disks of young stars where orbital timescales of mere months should allow any complex structures to be tracked in real-time.

The main goal of the project on the Georgia State University's side was to
to develop open-source next-generation image reconstruction algorithms
based on machine-learning and compressed sensing, advances critically
needed to take advantage of the multi-wavelength information and to
image the dynamic, time-changing dust emission with minimal artifacts. Since
interferometric imaging is an inverse problem, the regularized maximum
likelihood (Maximum A Posteriori) approach can be adopted. The
fidelity of the reconstructions then critically depends on the chosen spatial,
spectral and temporal regularizations. Thanks to this grant, Prof. Baron worked on the open-source OITOOLS framework, and made available to the community new multi-wavelength and multi-epoch image reconstruction algorithms.

imaging from real MIRCX and MYSTIC data, we focused on the two most interesting systems showing day to day variability, and therefore indicating some interesting physics at play: v1295 Aql (Ibrahim et al., 2023, published in the Astrophysical Journal) and MWC 275 (Setterholm et al., to be submitted in 2024). In the case of v1295 Aql, we have developed an empiral law to fit the flux distribution of the dust disk (i.e. our double sigmoid model) which significantly departs from most theoretical predictions based on radiative transfer. The variability can be clearly seen in our two reconstructed images, which show a sub-AU structure that seems to move between epochs inconsistently with Keplerian motion. It is for the moment unclear what we are truly seeing: a potential stellar companion, some structure linked to forming exoplanets, or also possibly some asymmetries in the dust density distribution or illumination of the circumstellar material? Similarly, for MWC 275, we have uncovered a highly active environment at the inner-edge of the planet formation region, with a clumpy feature near the dust-sublimation radius, moving twice slower than the local Keplerian velocity. At this stage, while we can't rule out completely instrumental effects and algorithm artefacts, it seems very likely that we are witnessing never-before-seen physics at work.
Since understanding this physics with little data is difficult, Prof. Baron started developing a new code based on deep imaging (Glow and UNet neural networks) which can provide better quality imaging from fewer interferometric measurments than conventional algorithms. This code in now being thoroughly tested in simulations before we apply it to real MIRCX/MYSTIC data. What is certain, is that future CHARA observations coupled with these new image reconstruction algorithms will give us a good chance of definitively piercing some of these mysteries of planet formation.
